list.title: An event is serious (based on the ICH definition) when the patient outcome is:

body.p: A 19-year-old woman developed metabolic acidosis following treatment with sodium chloride during pregnancy.

The G2P1001 woman, who had obesity and prior gestational hypertension, presented at 33 weeks of gestation at an institution with confusion for 1 day. She reported chest pain, dyspnoea, tachypnoea and reduced appetite with associated nausea and vomiting. She was initiated on sodium chloride [normal saline] infusions [dosage and indication not stated]. Brain CT showed bilateral thalamic hypodensities. She was transferred to another institution. Upon admission, she was awake but globally aphasic. She had a right homonymous hemianopsia, left gaze preference, and reduced movement of the right upper extremity. Laboratory investigation revealed metabolic acidosis. The metabolic acidosis was attributed to sodium chloride and underlying severe starvation ketosis.

The woman was treated with bicarbonate infusions and isotonic fluid. Thereafter, her metabolic acidosis resolved. SARS-CoV-2 PCR was performed and was found to be positive. She was initiated on high-dose thiamine for a presumptive diagnosis of Wernicke's encephalopathy. Fetal heart tones were found to be non-reassuring. She required intubation due to respiratory distress. Post-intubation, fetal heart tones became prolonged with recurrent late decelerations. She underwent emergent bedside cesarean section. The neonate [neonate gender not stated] was intubated and transferred to the neonatal ICU. Subsequently, the woman was diagnosed with acute necrotizing encephalopathy (ANE) secondary to COVID-19. She was treated with methylprednisolone and prednisone for ANE. Her condition improved and she was extubated. She was discharged to an acute rehabilitation facility. The infant was also ultimately discharged home in healthy condition.

ref.mixed-citation: Breit H, et al. Acute necrotizing encephalopathy due to SARS-CoV-2 in a pregnant female. Neurological Sciences 42: 3991-3994, No. 10, 2021. Available from: URL: 10.1007/s10072-021-05518-2PMC831969034324121
